Reviews.Content: Bought this camera as a starter for my daughter.  We so far like the camera.  I was upset with Amazon with the purchase suggestion of the memory card and case.  I bought them as a package in trust.  When she opened the gift.  The camera does not fit in the case.  Can't return as she tore the packaging, just have to take it as a lesson learned.  Just want to warn others before they buy the same thing.

Reviews.Title: Perfect for campers
Reviews.Author: Eileen Esposito
Reviews.Content: This is going to be a Christmas present for my grandson, who likes to go camping with his scout troop. He has already tried this model, and liked it because it runs on batteries, it can't be recharged. There is no way to recharge anything when you're not around any electric outlets!

Reviews.Title: I like the digital camera ...
Reviews.Author: R. Hwang "abigguy"
Reviews.Content: I like this camera; it was the 3rd camera I owned; Canon is a great brand; I like the way you use the flash!!

Reviews.Title: Replace one that was damaged ....
Reviews.Author: Manley Brahs
Reviews.Content: I had the same camera before and because I needed to replace one that was damaged I decided to buy the same model which I liked .

Reviews.Title: Nice, simple.
Reviews.Author: Justa Guy
Reviews.Content: This is the second PowerShot we have owned.  the first one was still a great camera, but I wanted a camera with some updated features and a few more available megapixels.  This one also has a 16x zoom which is a great thing to have.  Oh, and it uses AA batts which are available anywhere.  No expensive spare batteries or chargers to carry around.  If it goes dead, throw a couple of new batts in it.  It has a solid feel, and yes, it takes great pictures.  the colors seem natural and balanced, and the exposures seem to be center weighted, with a dose of "fuzzy logic" thrown in.  I have to try to trick it into a bad exposure or an autofocus problem.  Just point and shoot and you'll be fine.  It can be run full auto, or you can use shutter or aperture priority.  Dont forget the HD video which is only limited by how big a card you put in it.It does tend to suck batteries, so keep an extra set or two handy.  The flash is not automatic on this model, which I didnt like at first.  But not having the flash charge every time you turn the camera on definitely makes this one suck batteries less than our old one.I'm very happy with the PowerShot....again.

Reviews.Title: Don't like Power source
Reviews.Author: Peter S. Pavlis
Reviews.Content: I really like the camera, it takes great pictures.  I didn't check the power source when I bought it and it uses batteries.  My other Canon cameras all use Lithium Ion.  This camera gets used a lot and it eats batteries

Reviews.Title: Works great
Reviews.Author: Michael John Keady III
Reviews.Content: Nice pictures, inexpensive camera. The only issue is at times it takes awhile to autofocus. But it is a great camera. Have taken a lot of great pictures of puppies and they come out great.

Reviews.Title: Absolutely love it
Reviews.Author: Amy
Reviews.Content: It was exactly as I expected it to be. It was more or less love at first sight and I would recommend it for those wanting a nice camera not too pricey, with good quality (just in my personal opinion)

Reviews.Title: Nice Size
Reviews.Author: Patrick Flanigan
Reviews.Content: I like the camera and all it's functions but I miss the view finder, I think you can frame the picture much better through a view finder. Outside shots in sunny conditions is very difficult to see through the LCD viewer. Most of the time I have to guess what I have in the viewer.........

Reviews.Title: A little heavy for a purse
Reviews.Author: Tim Trischuk
Reviews.Content: Bought this for my wife based on specifications, and the fact that it takes AA batteries instead of needing a charger.  Unfortunately she finds it too big and heavy to carry around.  Most cameras are also pretty complicated these days, but she'll just have to spend some time with the manual.  I opted for the AA battery simplicity rather than a super compact that you have to remember to recharge, but the jury's still out on whether that was the right compromise.

Reviews.Title: Great camera
Reviews.Author: Thomas Fournet
Reviews.Content: Great camera, all the features work well. Only bad thing I could find is it has very short battery life.

Reviews.Title: Good camera - inferior support
Reviews.Author: Auggie
Reviews.Content: I have been using this camera for a few months now and am satisfied with its ease of use and quality of the pictures. But after just a few months' use it would not hold my date, time and time zone info so that everytime I powered up the camera I'd have to re-enter the information or do without the date stamp. Because I need the date stamp on my photos I don't opt out of the data entry step. It was quite a pain. I assumed a problem with an internal NiCad.I called Canon's 800 number and was pleased that a support person got right on the phone. Turns out there isn't an internal NiCad but there is a hearing-aid type battery that powers the date memory. The technician told me how to access the battery for replacement - doing so was simple - and then instructed me to replace it. I told him I'd only had the camera a few months and shouldn't be expected to buy what should have been a long-lasting component. I expected him to offer to mail me a replacement battery. Instead he said the batteries are new when placed in the camea in the factory.When I told him I bought the camera new and should not have to replace it so soon he said I could always send the camera back to them for "repair," knowing full well what a hassle that would be. What he should have done was apologize for the inconvenience and offer to send me a replacement battery in the mail.I would suggest if you're camera shopping and trying to decide between this camera and another, all things being equal be sure to factor in my customer service experience when balancing pros from cons.

Reviews.Title: good pictures but one drawback
Reviews.Author: averageman
Reviews.Content: I found this camera a nice choice for a reasonably priced digital with good zoom capabilities.  But there is one drawback, no option to use a viewfinder.  When I am taking outdoor photos in very sunny conditions, I can not always see the screen image well, and would have appreciated a viewfinder for this situation.  But the photos are clear and have good image quality.

Reviews.Title: Nice point & shoot
Reviews.Author: Warren
Reviews.Content: This camera was bought for my kids.  My son took it to Washington D.C. 3 days after we got it. He shot in the neighborhood of 600 pictures.  Some came out outstanding. Seems to be a bit lacking in the low light area. That was expected by me & was explained in the reviews.  I have used it very little. I told my son, who is 14 that he may be able to offset the low light limitations by reading the manual that Canon provided.  His comment was..."I'll figure it out dad. Don't worry".  Both kids like it very well though.  Wish I had a camera that nice when I was 14.

Reviews.Title: Not a good point-and-shoot camera for action photos
Reviews.Author: oldquilt "oldquilt"
Reviews.Content: I did read all the reviews before buying this camera so I knew what I was getting. Lots of complaints about the fact there is no SD card with this camera, so I knew I would have to buy one or find one before using this.  I agree, that should be in the description.  Since the last two cameras I bought had an inexpensive one included, I was a little surprised by that.  Maybe that is how Canon keeps the price down.The batteries are also cheap and even though I replaced them with lithium batteries immediately, it really didn't help the slow recharging-the-flash problem.  You have to wait several seconds before taking the next picture.  Great if all the pictures you take are still life, but it is not a good point and shoot if you want to take a series of action photos.  It's nice that they are AA though.

Reviews.Title: my ratings.......
Reviews.Author: walter thomas
Reviews.Content: meets a lot of my specs......great pic and video quality.......optical zoom great.......sound super.......a great buy for the money and simple to operate.......only wish it could recharge battery after each pic taken.

Reviews.Title: Too slow
Reviews.Author: Reflection "Superwoman"
Reviews.Content: Takes way too long in between shots.  I have toddlers and need something that will let me take shots continuously and quickly.  Looking for something better

Reviews.Title: Canon camera
Reviews.Author: Donna R. Kleintjes
Reviews.Content: This camera met all of our expectations.  We had previously owned the PowerShot SX 120 IS, and this 160 takes better pictures while being somewhat easier to use.  There is an image stabilization feature on this camera which maintains clarity of the photo even if the camera is slightly moved.I would definitely buy this again.

Reviews.Title: Great for the price.
Reviews.Author: Keen Eye
Reviews.Content: I love this camera and would recommend it. It's small but easy to handle. The photo quality is great. The settings are easy to use. The only drawback is it EATS batteries.

Reviews.Title: Canon PowerShot SX160
Reviews.Author: Diana
Reviews.Content: This is a replacement for my older, larger Canon. I like this camera, but it is taking some getting used to (at 67 change is a little difficult for me). Zoom is fantastic, I take a lot of wildlife shots from a quarter mile or more. I'm very pleased with the results.

Reviews.Title: Good
Reviews.Author: Pen Name
Reviews.Content: I WAS VERY PLEASED WITH THIS CAMERA IT IS VERY EASY TO USE I HAVE TAKEN MANY PICTURES AND THEY TURNED OUT NICE AND CLEAR

Reviews.Title: Horrible battery life, pictures similar to point and shoot
Reviews.Author: Mike
Reviews.Content: I read the reviews before buying, and even though a lot of people complained about battery life, I thought I'd give it a try (found a great deal for $69.)  I got the camera, and about 15 minutes into my photos had to put in new batteries.  Not even 40 minutes later, those were dead and I had to put in new batteries AGAIN.  The quality was similar to my point-and-shoot canon powershot with no noticeable advantages.  Despite the good deal (and the fact that all our batteries are free from couponing,) we STILL returned this camera because the battery life is so inconvenient.

Reviews.Title: perfect
Reviews.Author: traveler
Reviews.Content: This camera was a gift for my daughter who uses her phone constantly to take pictures of her kids - she loves the size and functions of this simple basic camera.  It takes really nice pics!

Reviews.Title: focus not easy zoom not good.
Reviews.Author: Genevieve OwensN
Reviews.Content: Do not like zoom that was main thing I bought it for. Is hard to focus.  Would not recomend it.

Reviews.Title: Excellent Zoom
Reviews.Author: Carmen L. Rodriguez
Reviews.Content: The only thing I dislike is the flash loading time and the waiting time between shots... but was a good purchase if you're not a pro. :)

Reviews.Title: Great little camera
Reviews.Author: JAV "Video Lover"
Reviews.Content: For a small point and shoot the camera takes pretty amazing photos:Pros:16x optical zoomCatches focus quicklyvery lightwell-builtdouble A battteriesCons:Flash is slow to rechargeUse lithium batteries as it runs through AA's quickly

Reviews.Title: Not a fast camera. Ergonomically, room for improvement.
Reviews.Author: Mike

} } } Length:: 1:33 MinsBottom line: The Canon SX160 is a good buy for the price point. It is not a Canon PowerShot SX260 HS 12.1 MP CMOS Digital Camera with 20x Image Stabilized Zoom 25mm Wide-Angle Lens and 1080p Full-HD Video (Black), which I suppose is what most of us really want in the end. (Better CMOS sensor, better 20x zoom, better 30fps HD video, better hi-res LCD. (Don't need no steekin' GPS. But the 240SX isn't sold in the USA.)) But the SX260 cost almost $100 more than what I paid for the SX160 and the SX260 doesn't run on AA batteries, which is of prime importance to me. If Canon made an AA version of the SX260, stuffing the better guts of the 260 into the body of the 160, I'd jump. But since Canon doesn't, the SX160 will suffice.Long review to follow. Pick and choose what you want to read.For comparison purposes, my previous camera, still working well, is a Canon PowerShot A540. A 6MP, 4x optical, AA powered, full featured camera. (Has Manual mode, for example.) I was looking to upgrade to a similar AA battery powered camera with Image Stabilization (IS) and more zoom. (Those expensive, proprietary Li-ions are always dying on you in the middle of nowhere. If you don't carry a spare, you need to carry a charger and find 120v AC. Whereas carrying or finding extra AA's with you on a trip is cheap backup.) The pickin's for AA powered cameras are slim.Pickin's are even slimmer if you're looking for a two-cell camera. (Four AA batteries, unless Lithium AA, make a camera too heavy for my taste.) At the time I bought the SX160, I could only find two candidates: One, the low end Canon's, like the Canon PowerShot A1300 16.0 MP Digital Camera with 5x Digital Image Stabilized Zoom 28mm Wide-Angle Lens with 720p HD Video Recording (Silver) for $100. And the SX160 for a little more.---------UPDATE - Check out the Sony DSC-H200 Digital Camera with 3-Inch LCD (Black). Costs about the same as the SX260. Not pocketable, and 4 cell. But might be a better camera. Optical zoom while recording video.UPDATE - I just learned about the Pentax X-5 Digital Camera with 26x Optical Zoom and 3" LCD (Black), a four cell AA camera. Fry's Electronics is selling it for $200 this week. CMOS sensor, 26x zoom, high display LCD, Electronic viewfinder, etc. It won't fit in your pocket, but some say the SX160 won't either and needs a case. See the customer image of the moon there and compare to mine here.UPDATE - There is now also the new Nikon COOLPIX L610 16 MP Digital Camera with 14x Zoom NIKKOR Glass Lens and 3-inch LCD (Black) two AA camera with arguably better specs: CMOS sensor, higher res LCD; 30fps HD video (plus slo-mo 60fps), glass lens, better ergonomic body design. All for the same price as the SX160. (But no optical zoom when recording movies.) The L610 is narrowly focused on the "point and shoot" consumer market only. It doesn't have PASM which would be a deal breaker for many.----------The A1300 would have met my requirements, albeit a 5x zoom isn't much of an increase from my ol' 4x. But you get a lot more bang for the buck with the SX160.So when the price of the SX160 dropped to $150, I jumped. I bought it with a Transcend 16 GB SDHC Class 10 Flash Memory Card TS16GSDHC10E card that Amazon impulse-marketed me when I ordered the camera, which is more than enough capacity. (Update: And which CrystalDiskMark's above 10MB/sec write.)Since everyone else here is focusing on the positives, I'll primarily focus on the negatives to round out the reviews. (camera. focus. negatives. get it?) UPDATE: For example, as others are saying here, it is a tad slow with respect to shutter lag. Been taking pictures of a very energetic spaniel. Seems to be about a 1/4 second delay in what the camera captures after I press the shutter - even with the focus and exposure set to manual (so that there's nothing for the camera to think about).And so that you know as you read this review, I never used the automatic features in my A540, like the AUTO mode or AiAF. I don't expect to be using these or all the new "tracking, face finding, anti-blink" stuff they've put in the SX160 now. (Although they are fascinating to watch in action.) I know how to focus, and I primarily use the Program mode for 99% of my photos.Ergonomics: My previous camera, the Canon Powershot A540, had a protrusion on the right front of the body, near where the batteries go, which made a fantastic hand hold. (A so-called "Grip.") Exactly like what Canon still does on the A3100. (And A810.) Such a grip places your finger more naturally on the shutter button and zoom control too. (See my customer images.)Unfortunately, even though Canon knew how to do it with the A540 and knows how do it in the A3100, the SX160IS does not have this important ergonomic feature. (Sometime shortly after the A540, the body design on the PowerShots changed to resemble the ELPH's. Now they've brought back the old A540 style in the A3100. It's what customers want.) In fact, since there's no grip per se and since the camera is heavier (bigger lens) and longer, it tends to lever out of your hand. You cannot easily hold the camera with one hand without it rotating CCW.They put a chrome-colored strip on the front to give your fingertips a place to anchor, but that's more like using your fingertips while rock climbing. As such, you'll definitely want to use the wrist strap (included) with this camera as a safety net for when it slips and falls out of your hand.(See my fuzzy strip mod in customer images which makes the camera significantly easier to hold.) As it is now, you have to pinch the camera with your thumb and fingers. (More on that later.) Which makes it basically a two-handed camera.As such, I often end up unintentionally covering up the AF assist beam with a finger, since it's kinda close to the upper left part of the camera.Zoom noise in video: Unlike reviewer Yarii's, my camera was made in Malaysia. (Not Japan, like hers.) And unlike reviewer Yarii's, I can hear more "zoom noise" (a "whirring" of gears) in my camera than hers when zooming while taking movies. (Find her video on YT by searching for "Canon SX160 Zoom Motor Noise Test." Turn your volume up all the way if you want to hear the noise.) I've posted a sample video with this review of what mine sounds like during zoom.The manual warns the camera might record mechanical noise while zooming. Fair enough. Better than muting the audio, as some manufacturers do. I noticed, during the many takes of making my video for you, the whirring came and went. So maybe after the gears "break in" (what a horrible thought) the noise will stop?Battery compartment: The markings that show the proper orientation for the AA batteries are merely black letters in the black plastic inside the black (dark) battery compartment. Hard for aging eyes to see the polarity marks. See my Metallic Sharpie mod in customer images to mitigate this.Read the Manual: For the most part, the menu and buttons are like my old A540. But different enough that I'm going to have to read the PDF manual on the CD.Nit: Unfortunately, the CD won't play in my computer. (A late model PC.) Will try in someone elses box and see what happens. (Update: CD plays in a friend's computer. Cheap media?) BTW, the User's Guide on the Canon website is now up to version CDD. (Revised from CDC on the CD. I don't know what changed.)Features & more ergonomics: After reading the User Guide (twice) - wow, what a feature rich camera! I doubt I'll be able to remember all the trick things it can do. (And I'm an engineer type, who finds it easy to remember geeky stuff like that.) Among them are several "safety features." The camera can automatically keep you from overexposing on flash. You can set it to double check your focus for you when you use Manual Focus. Etc. (I said I don't use that Auto stuff. But I do let it help me here.) UPDATE: I've been experimenting with continuous focus, tracking AF, servo AF, etc. while taking pictures of a very energetic spaniel. It's not clear to me what the subtle differences are of those features. It would help if Canon would explain more in the manual how Servo AF differs from say, Tracking AF, and why you'd select one over the other.====UPDATE: Just got back from taking photos from a small plane. I dearly miss the old "Landscape" scene mode, which set the Manual Focus to infinity for you. I can set the Manual focus to infinity by hand on the SX160 (3 steps), but since I have Safety MF set to ON, the camera often decrements the focus in flight down from infinity. I dunno why. Maybe it sees a reflection on the canopy? Clouds aren't the easiest thing to focus on either. So now I need to remember to do a fourth step to take landscapes: turn off Safety MF.16:9 format simply cuts off the top and bottom of 4:3 format. Better to leave the camera in 4:3 and crop at home for 16:9 as you desire.So Canon, how about a dedicated Landscape mode again that sets MF to infinity and turns off Safety MF? There's room on the Mode dial for it.====Even if I could remember all the trick things it could do, it's difficult to make it do them all. That's because some features require you press half way down the smallish shutter button while simultaneously pressing another button on the camera, presumably with your thumb. There's a small thumb friction pad area on the back side of the camera, expecting you'll be pinching the camera there to hold it. But when your thumb-your opposing grip-moves to push a button, you lose your grip on the camera! So if you move your thumb to access one of these two step inputs, you need to use two hands.But even if I could do the tricks, I don't want to do all the trick things this camera can do. Why would I want to fisheye a photo in the camera? Why not take a good shot and fisheye it later on software at home? Same with B/W scene. I can take the color out at home. Or why would I edit a shot on a dinky lowish res LCD on the camera when I can edit it on a larger laptop or desktop screen later?[I haven't played much with the AUTO mode, but it's clear a lot of the resources of this camera were spent on first time users (i.e., point and shoot) who apparently want gee-whiz gimmickry tricks. Like "Read my mind and take the picture for me."]Image Stabilization inconsistency: The manual says that YOU need to turn off image stabilization when on tripod. Others here say it turns off automatically. As does the description here on Amazon: "When tripod use is detected, the Image Stabilizer is stopped because it is not needed." Which is it?Ahhh... the answer is that when the Intelligent IS notices that the camera isn't moving (via the built in accelerometer), the IS turns off. Goes into "tripod" mode." But it doesn't really detect a tripod. It'll go into "tripod" mode if stationary on a table.However, in any other mode but Auto, the User Guide says you need to turn IS off when using a tripod. Why? Simply to save power? I dunno. Does it affect picture quality? Apparently it could. I found this quote in a Samsung camera manual about their IS mode with tripod: "If you use the OIS function with a tripod, your images may be blurred by the vibration of the OIS sensor. Deactivate the OIS function when using a tripod." Interesting. As an engineer, I can understand how dithering of the IS due to circuit noise could degrade an image if taken on tripod. So, then, maybe you should turn IS off when on tripod?But upon more testing, I found this isn't necessary with the SX160. The IS turns off automatically in any mode when on tripod. It just won't annunciate to you with an icon that IS has turned off (that is, entering "tripod mode") as shows in AUTO. So the Guide seems inconsistent, telling you to turn IS off on tripod. You don't have to.[I've taken demanding shots of the a street sign at night at 15 seconds (ISO 100, f5.6 full zoom) in M mode on a tripod with IS manually enabled/disabled. (See my customer image.) No difference that I can discern with IS on/off when pixel peeking. Moreover, I can jiggle the camera on the tripod with IS ostensibly enabled but I can tell the IS has turned itself off. (That is, when I jiggle the camera, the LCD image will jiggle for a half second, showing the IS was off. And then it'll suddenly lock in after the camera is jiggled, showing the IS comes back on. So the camera does turn IS off automatically for you when the camera is stationary.]More ergonomics: The four way multi-button has a rotating bezel around it. Hmmm... some cute feature someone in Marketing came up with? You can do almost everything with the Left/Right toggle that you can do by rotating the bezel. But there are a few things you can ONLY do with the Left/Right toggle that you can't do by rotating the bezel. And there are a few things you can only do with the bezel you can't do with the buttons. So it's inconsistent and I often find myself hitting left/right when I should rotate. They should change it so you use one or the other for certain tasks, but not both.FWIW, I'm a 6 foot skinny man, and my hands aren't as large as your average mid-west farmer type male. I can spin the bezel fairly well, but I sometimes toggle left/right by accident when rotating the bezel. I'd be surprised if a large burly man with big fingers can use it well. (A timer that inhibited toggle for a quarter second after using the bezel would minimize this problem.)Blinkie: Not stated obviously in the User Guide (I didn't understand what they were trying to say until I searched the web on how to read histograms and learned about "Blinkies"), one of the Display pages for reviewing your photos (the page with the histogram) blinks overexposed parts of your image in pseudo-reverse video. Canon might want to offer blinkie off/on on the basic review page too. A very handy feature.Counter-intuitive Movie mode: The way Movie mode works is counter-intuitive. On my old A540 (and another reviewer here tells me as late as the SX130), when you were in the Movie mode and pushed the shutter button, guess what? It started taking movies! But now it takes a snapshot. (But I have no idea what mode it takes a snapshot in when you're in Movie mode. Does it revert to Auto? Your "P" settings?) Anyway, when in the Movie mode, you still have to press the Movie button to start a movie. (A reviewer here says the Movie button will follow certain scene settings. The manual implies that too. It does, but it's subtle. For example, taking a movie at night in Fireworks mode makes the colors of street lights a little more orangish.)Maybe I'm missing something, but I see no reason to ever switch to Movie mode on this camera to take a movie. I'll just start movies from the "P" mode, where I'm usually at. (A YouTube reviewer on the Canon SX260 says you only go into Movie mode to select iFrame format. The Guide says you can control exposure ("brightness") of movies only in the Movie mode.)It records movie audio in "stereo." Two mics, maybe two inches apart. Pretty useless stereo. Perhaps a marketing feature. Hey, Canon, if you're reading this, if you go back to mono and phase the two mic's, maybe you can get some directionality out of them? THAT would really be a marketing feature!Another "neat idea", wouldn't it be neat if the Auto-magnify AF thingie painted a green box around the zoom area after it acquired focus? That would give more user feedback that you've locked focus.Another neat feature would be "Maximum AUTO ISO." That is, I'd like to set it so it can select the ISO automatically but not go past 400. (For example.) Graininess is too much past 400. (Either that or make the images less noisy in the first place.)Paparazzi mode: Continuous mode shooting is a lot slower than my old A540. The SX160 isn't anywhere near as fast as old film cameras that you'd hear go "click, click, click." (Tested with M1, Fine on the SX160.) Interestingly, the delay doesn't seem to be longer at L. Or shorter at S and Superfine. Must be a bottleneck elsewhere.In the manual, it says the special low light level scene will take fast continuous shots. it's true. It flies in that mode. 2.8 shots/sec according to the Guide. (But no Date stamp. I wonder what else they're not post processing?) But who's going to remember you have to take two steps to get into this fast continuous mode? (Incidentally, in this low light mode, I've seen ISO as high as 6400.)[Here's an interesting test to see how long it takes Canon to post-process before writing to your SD card. Take the SD card out and take a photo. It'll be a second or so before the camera tells you it can't write the image to memory. So it's doing a lot of thinking in there. I wonder if we're really making progress with fancy processors and the push for more MP?]Wish list: I realize I'm asking too much at this price point, but I miss a viewfinder for sunny days when it's hard to see the screen. Even an Electronic Viewfinder would be helpful, although where would they put it with the flash there already? (Moving the flash where there did on the SX160 and making it pop up with a push of a button was a big improvement over the auto popup many reviewers didn't like on the Canon SX230.) Anyway, I can see the screen in direct sun in Arizona. Usable, albeit a little washed out. (I really like that "Hold the DISP button to get max brightness" feature.) Glare is sometimes a problem and I sometimes see the reflection of my face in the LCD. (Of course I put a screen protector on the LCD.)Flash: Speaking of flash, the new Slow Syncho feature is a clever way to mitigate the notorious weak flash in the PowerShot line. Effectively increases the flash range.I notice too that the flash recharge/recycle time is faster than my old A540, using the same batteries. So that's better. But it still takes a second or two between flash shots.===UPDATE: I have my SX160 set for 3 seconds of detailed review, so I can study the photo and histogram of the image I just took. But when you use flash, the display shuts off immediately after a shot while the flash is charging. Canon does that so they can send more power to charge the flash and recycle faster. But by the time the flash charges, the review timeout is over and you can't see the image you just took!I wonder if Canon could stuff two BFC's (Big Fat Capacitor) in there for the flash, alternating between them to drive the flash? That way, after taking one flash picture, you'd have the second BFC come on line, already charged for the next shot. The capacitor that just drained can then charge more leisurely in the background so the display can stay on all the time. Call it "Burst2Flash" and patent it.===Zooming on Zoom: Interestingly, the zoom lever is not pressure sensitive. You're either zooming or you're not. At full speed. No fast/slow. I never noticed it's that way on my old A540 too. But there's so much zoom on the SX160, the motor is too fast for me for still images. (It's slower when taking movies, per my video clip above.) It's hard to frame a zoom shot just right for stills. Seems like Canon figured you'd be either all in or all out. They should either slow the zoom down (easy firmware fix) or make a two step zoom. (Expensive hardware change.)Quality Control: I have one or two pixels stuck somewhere. (Brand new out of the box.) When I go into a dark room and look at the display, I see two pixels stuck on the LCD. (User Guide says this can't be helped.) When I take a photo of the moon and review it on the computer, I see one stuck pixel in the actual image. See my customer image, above. (I called Canon. One pixel does not a defective camera make for warranty return purposes. Said they would fix if very obviously bad.)Otherwise, the picture quality seems fine to me, even at L SF. Dynamic range is best with L SF. (Since a 16GB card holds 1000 L SF images, and since the camera isn't any slower processing L SF images, I see no reason to not use L SF all the time. Better to have too much image data than too little.)A UK magazine review was critical of the image quality, saying it was only average. Said noise starts to be a problem at ISO 200 and up. Yes, there's about 30% more noise from 100 to 200. (A WAG. Hey, it's only a CCD sensor. Not CMOS.) But pictures seem as good, if not better, than my old A540. So I'm content. (After doing my moon shot, I searched Google images and found some shots of the moon like mine, taken with 20X Canon cameras. They were amazing. But those were $500 CMOS units with better lenses.)Conclusion: While I said this review would focus mostly on the negative, if you can live with the ergonomic shortcomings (I can) it's a good buy. Especially at this price point. Especially considering I'm moving up from an old Canon A540. I simply wanted an improved version of it, an AA powered camera with more zoom, image stabilization, (silent) optical zoom in movie mode and better flash. (I don't care about HD video. 640 at 30fps is fine for YouTube and Amazon reviews.) This is a big improvement for me. If you're coming from last year's model, say the Canon SX150, maybe not so much.The SX160 IS is about as close as I can get right now to the grown up A540 I wanted. A camera to throw in my bag or pocket, to always have with me whenever I need a camera that's better than a cell phone camera. I don't need a perfect image. Just one that's good enough. (And truth be told, most of us look at images on screen anyway nowadays.)

Reviews.Title: Power In A Box
Reviews.Author: JohnHaydenInMd dot com
Reviews.Content: First time I've had a state-of-the-art digital camera. It's not the most powerful camera on the market, but it's exactly what I need to make my blog better, and it's in my price range. The lack of a more detailed paper manual has hindered my learning curve of all the features. The manual is on disk. All I use is the automatic mode, but that's really all I need right now.  The PowerShot SX160 on automatic is professional quality point-and-shoot photography for dummies. Highly recommend it.

Reviews.Title: this camera is not for action shots!
Reviews.Author: Pablo Ayllon
Reviews.Content: All my action shots are blurry. I bought this camera for my wife as a Christmas present. We took pictures of the kids opening presents and all the pictures turned out badly, unless they were motionless! I looked at the documentation, and went online in an attempt to find a solution, but all the suggestion for settings did not work. Engineering foresight and capability to improve on existing products were not displayed well with this model.In my humble opinion, this is not a well rounded camera for family's with active kids.On the positive side, it does take good still photos.BTW, someone recently asked whether or not the software is compatible with apple's OS. Yes, it is compatible with MAC OS 10.6- 10.7

Reviews.Title: Slow record time - so so pictures
Reviews.Author: Shane
Reviews.Content: I bought this to replace a 5 year old canon powershot 5MP.  I had hoped it would be a an improved model with better speed,better pictures, etc.  No such luck.Pros: Solid feel nice zoom.Cons: very slow picture capture.  flash required charging between pictures - slowed down picture taking even more.  pictures I did take were grainy and not what I expected from a Canon 16MP camera

Reviews.Title: Canon powershot
Reviews.Author: blevin
Reviews.Content: Received the camera really quick. Went to use it and it took great pic's. When I tried to upload the pic's it wouldnt work. Called Canon and went through many steps to try and get it to work. Canon then had the camera shipped back to them and replace it with a new camers. It works just fine.

Reviews.Title: Very good but could be better
Reviews.Author: MAURO M.
Reviews.Content: I would have preferred to stay in 12 mp , as the 16 mp sensor produces more noise. For the price, is the best compact camera with manual controls and batteries aa, already say that swallows alkaline batteries , but with a smart charger with refresh cycle ( I bought one for less than 30 dollars ) and battery hybrid as the sanyo eneloop , maha imedion 2400, Ansmann max -e 2500, is another story, perhaps better than many compact lithium batteries , if already ... many will say they are costs attachments are to the camera, but I guarantee which is much cheaper than buying a charger and extra battery for a camera that uses lithium battery proprietary type (which can cost up to 80 dollars or more if you buy the original brand , because the imitations are good for nothing ) , for example, I purchase 4 of 4 batteries aa combos imedion 2400 (total 16 ) for 44 bucks and sony charger with refresh cycle for 28 dollars , meaning I have the equivalent of 8 changes battery and charger for only 72 dollars (I forget to change batteries for all my vacation, since these batteries only lose 25 % of their power after a year , for those who want to save, every 4 batteries are sold for 12 dollars , okay buy only 8 batteries ) . Also these batteries are more consistent with the use of flash .If we add the ability of many manual settings, zoom good enough to be compact and price, and some reduction in size compared to its predecessors , we have a winner of 4 stars , the only reason I did not give 5 stars is because . canon was tempted to increase the megapixels to 16, for marketing purposes , and this produced that its picture quality is fine for the price but now the images have more noise. (which is acceptable for this price but a deterioration with respect to the sensors 12 and 14 Mp) . For less than 145 dollars is very good camera for those who like manual controls and AA batteries .Now that canon, decided to change the sx series , with the new model sx 170 lithium batteries , the canon sx 160 becomes an added value, because for 200 dollars or more , one would recommend the canon sx 260 or higher models. For its low price and aa batteries , now more than ever the sx160 is a good option .

Reviews.Title: Disappointment
Reviews.Author: Lance Axness
Reviews.Content: Added expense for digital lack of quality and battery Hog.  Get a smaller simpler camera.  This was cumbersome. Slow to flash.

Reviews.Title: Very Disappointed
Reviews.Author: C. Anderson
Reviews.Content: I tried out this camera and did not get good images.  They looked fine on the viewer, but when I uploaded them to my computer every picture had pixelation or was blurry.  I sent it back.  Very disappointed in Canon.

Reviews.Title: not as good a previous canons
Reviews.Author: mc "mc"
Reviews.Content: I own an EOS rebel xt, an powershot A520, and an A1000IS(until it was stolen).  Replaced the A100IS w/sx160.  The SX160 does not take good pics on auto mode. The slightest movement of the subject comes out blurry, which never happened in former models. I have tried to compensate by using the Tv function and raising the shutter speed, which works fine for a closer subject(~5ft), but for farther away, the shot is too dark. Unlike previous models, this one lacks a detailed printed user manual enclosed. I found the manuals great, small enough to carry in my purse, or throw in my carry-on bag.  I am not a pro, and the manual really helped learn all the features and best uses for manual modes. So without a manual, I am having a hard time addressing the blurring problem. On the positive side, the battery life is good and it resets between pics noticeably faster than previous cameras. It seems durable.

Reviews.Title: Has issues
Reviews.Author: Marilyn Schmidt
Reviews.Content: This camera diffiently has issues. Difficult to use. Slow recovery after each shot and the batteries died in one day. Sent it back for a replacement and had all the same issues.

Reviews.Title: Not so great
Reviews.Author: Doreen T Fahringer
Reviews.Content: Well, Not as great as I expected.  Have to wait between shots for flash to recharge.  Buy a better canon.

Reviews.Title: as expected
Reviews.Author: Amazon Customer
Reviews.Content: Arrived on time, but I haven't used it yet. Taking it on my oversea trip in 2 weeks. However, I like the feel and smallness of he camera.

Reviews.Title: No protective plastic on lense-sent back;-(
Reviews.Author: Momma Wheats
Reviews.Content: Don't ever except an item where the protective covers are missing cause it means it's been a return and forgot to redo the plastic protection before sending it to another. Bummer

Reviews.Title: Great camera if you hold it as firm as possible.
Reviews.Author: TREVA CAMPBELL
Reviews.Content: Great camera if you hold it as firm as possible.  It must be made to be placed on a tripod. The pictures are blurry if you don't hold it tight and don't breathe.  I don't know if my husband will ever be able to take a good picture using it..  I guess he will have to use my other camera which is a Canon Power Shot SX 130.  I bought this SX 160 so we will have two cameras with us when we go to Alaska this summer.

Reviews.Title: Takes AA batteries
Reviews.Author: Ryan Guzman
Reviews.Content: The only downside is the AA battery powering.  Photo quality is as advertised! I also like the wide-angle and zoom work very well.

Reviews.Title: Sucks fresh batteries to death within minutes
Reviews.Author: Bette
Reviews.Content: There are many reviews for this product already, so I will stick with my main complaint, which is battery life.  I only wish to use electronic devices that are compatible with rechargeable batteries.  This Canon does not even register rechargeables!  The message is "Change the batteries."  Even when using extra fresh, package-just-opened-expiration-date-2017 name brand batteries, the camera only registers at LOW BATTERY.  I get maybe 3 pics and then it powers off, and using the ZOOM feature uses such a ridiculous amount of power that it alone will power off the cam.  In between shots, I have to turn off the camera altogether in order for the cam have any power for the next shot.  Ridiculous.

Reviews.Title: Uses to many batteries to fast
Reviews.Author: Kurt
Reviews.Content: The camera uses the battery power much to fast and they need replacement far to often. I returned the camera and upgrade to a cannon sx170 is which has its own dedicated battery and does;t use AA batteries. I am very pleased with this purchase and have taken many pictures without a battery recharge. Great Camera.

Reviews.Title: Canon Power Shot SX 160
Reviews.Author: Delmar R Wolfe
Reviews.Content: Camera seems great-really haven't used it much-the big test will be in April on a Panama Canal Cruise.  We have had Canon Products in the past and they have performed very well.

Reviews.Title: Great for moms and grandmas - but not what this "prosumer" would use himself.
Reviews.Author: Big in Portland
Reviews.Content: Bought this of rmy mom and she loves it. Great quality. Uses AA batteries which was convenient for her so she didn't have to keep track of a charger. But I did buy her rechargeable batteries so that comment might not be very helpful. Anyway - great image quality for snapshots and album prints. Great for moms and grandma.I carry a Fujifilm X100s for better image quality, but I'm a nerd.

Reviews.Title: I bought this camera on May 29th
Reviews.Author: jdbarnhart
Reviews.Content: It's October 31st and is not working any more.  The seller only gives a 1 month warranty from 5/29 to 6/29.  But Cannon gives you a 1 year warranty.  So, if you have this camera save all of your paperwork in case you need to send it back to Cannon for a refund or a re-worked camera or monies towards a new camera.Janet B

Reviews.Title: Almost, not quite
Reviews.Author: Book Lover
Reviews.Content: I previously had a canon powershot, I think it was an sx100, or very similar, and I loved it. When it died I wanted to replace it with something as similar as possible and I thought this was it. Unfortunately, they moved some of the control buttons to different places, specifically they switched the on/off button and the shutter and they added some buttons. I find it hard to hold this camera without pushing a button I don't want. There is very little room for fingers.

Reviews.Title: Very Good Camera!
Reviews.Author: Joseph F M Kelley
Reviews.Content: Good Working Camera with Nice Features and PC & Mac compatible software!  We were able to use the camera immediately!!

Reviews.Title: Good for the price
Reviews.Author: Dane Albright
Reviews.Content: Slow motion when taking multiple pictures.  Have to wait for the process time in order to shoot again.Good handling, extra features are nice.

Reviews.Title: One of my faves.
Reviews.Author: Stephanie
Reviews.Content: With a relative addicted to HSN I've tried so many cameras. This is one of my favorites. The SX160 has a built in image stabilizer that really works well. Sitting or standing I can take clear pictures even at 20x optical zoom. The settings are easy to use and figure out with each button clearly labeled. It's light weight and since it uses AA batteries you can easily take pictures all day without worrying about running out of juice. The flash is the only part that holds back from giving it 5 stars. It works beautifully but the charge time (though only a few seconds) did cause me to miss a few shots I would have liked to have gotten. Overall I'm quite pleased with this camera and will keep using it.

Reviews.Title: Canon PowerShot
Reviews.Author: Bb
Reviews.Content: Nice camera, fairly simple to use.  I bought the camera to take on vacation and it did a good job for me.  However, the length of time between clicks to take pictures is slow.

Reviews.Title: sx160
Reviews.Author: richard hampson
Reviews.Content: zooms too fast.too hard to get the zoom setting where it is wanted.takes good pictures.use on auto all the time

Reviews.Title: needs eyehole view finder and power saving features
Reviews.Author: Johnny Red "John"
Reviews.Content: This camera does not have an eyehole, you must use the view screen. In bright sunlight and some other light conditions it is impossible to see anything in the view screen. I have an older Canon A540 in which the batteries last for hundreds of pictures. This SX160 uses batteries at an unbelievable rate, sometimes I only got 50 to 75 pictures from one set of batteries. Picture quality is excellent. I bought this camera for the 16X zoom lens and was very pleased with its performance. If this camera had an eyehole to sight through and the view screen could be turned off to save power I would have given it 5 stars. When the camera is first turned on the option to enter a date, time and time zone is present. The camera would only remember this entry until it was turned off. When restarted it had to be reentered. In order to have camera remember the info it must be entered by going through the menu.

Reviews.Title: good Camera
Reviews.Author: Morris Shawen
Reviews.Content: Would be much better if the instructions contained on the disccame in hardcopy so one could carry it on trips to consult withwhen questions arise!

Reviews.Title: REMARKS ON CANON POWERSHOT SX160 MP DIGITAL CAMERA
Reviews.Author: Bob Walters
Reviews.Content: Have not used it a lot as of yet, but works fine and the instructions were very helpful.  Also the screen is of adequate size for viewing and composing shots.

Reviews.Title: Very good for the money
Reviews.Author: rojo
Reviews.Content: I love it; it is a handy size. Takes good pictures especially with the zoom lens. Only drawback is the not so clear screen.

Reviews.Title: Great Camera
Reviews.Author: Tiffany Haggerty
Reviews.Content: Takes wonderful pictures and I like the quality of the video camera.  The best part about this camera is the zoom.  It is fantastic!  The only thing I have a complaint on is the batter life.  I like that you use AA batteries and don't have to carry around a battery charger- but the AA drain really fast.

Reviews.Title: a good product
Reviews.Author: dennis
Reviews.Content: I'm just getting into digital photography and this was a good choice to start out with. Can take nice clear pics and the zoom works well. A bit of a lag between shots but for the price I can live with it.

Reviews.Title: Great
Reviews.Author: Linda Hand
Reviews.Content: I am looking forward to my first big trip so I can bring home great memories to share and remember.

Reviews.Title: Great Long Zoom
Reviews.Author: John M. Weaver
Reviews.Content: This is a upgrade from a older Canon PowerShot that we have had for years and still use.  This one has a longer zoom with 16 MP.  Gives you a lot for a great price in a very small pocket size.

Reviews.Title: SX 160 is has major errors
Reviews.Author: Fairview
Reviews.Content: I bought this camera because I was going to Luray Caverns in Virginia and wanted to take some good photos and because many reviews praised. The SX 160, is however, is a a disappointment. Here is why:1. It eats batteries. It really does chew them up like pacman.2. The flash is slow and therefore unreliable.3. When you zoom in the lens takes quite some time to adjust, by which time the 'shot' is gone, gone, gone.4. The stabilization is the worst I have ever experienced since I bought my first camera in 1978.5. I strongly recommend against this camera, with all due respect to Canon. PS. I had a Canon but lost it recently.

Reviews.Title: Great little camera
Reviews.Author: Mathwhz13
Reviews.Content: I have been using this camera for about a month now.  It takes great pictures with little thought.  I wanted a camera I did not have to constantly adjust or fiddle with the buttons and menu.  After the initial setup I have to do very little to get a great picture.  Love its light weight and portability.  I would buy this camera again.  Love it.

Reviews.Title: Awesome
Reviews.Author: Pen Name
Reviews.Content: It's awesome works great. I have no complaints. It's the best camera I have ever had. If your thinking about buying it do it. The camera came fast and was ready to go

Reviews.Title: Great Camera
Reviews.Author: jonathan stephens
Reviews.Content: I needed to buy new a camera after my Samsung died after 5 years or so,  one of my main decsiion factors on getting a new camera finding one that does not come with battery packs, I like being able to use to recharger AA batterys.  Well you will quickly find out that there are very few cameras that do not use a battery pack,  and it does not matter what price range, the under $100 cameras or higher priced cameras , there are only a few.So that was one reason why I chose this camera, and based off a lot reveiws I read, it seem to be a good buy, so I went for it, and so far I like it, I have had not even a month yet, so I am still getting use to it, but it takes great pics, and video's .  Like many have said, its not an action camera,  it can be if you have proper lighting,  and trying to take pics of a 16month that does not stand still very long can result in blurry pics, but so far, it has been well worth the money.One thing I am not liking so far is not having a battery meter on screen, or anywhere, there may be one, but I have not found it yet.  And on other thing I dont like, is not being able to pause while recording video, my 5/6 year camera could, my BB 9850 lets you pause while recoding .  But its still not a deal breaker, I guess if you want to shoot video, get a video camera lol.The size , well its not big, not small, its right in that middle area that might be too big to fit in pants pocket, unless you wear cargo pants( I do), or you are a female that carrys a very small purse( I am not, and dont),  this might a camera that if you want to carry around, you might want to get a camera belt case, or wear pants with big pockets.Other then those little things,  and dont let them put you off buying this camera, its a really decent camera.

Reviews.Title: Good for money
Reviews.Author: Antoni Stoychev
Reviews.Content: As far it's as good as I expected. I had more to learn for it and especially shooting in different mode than auto. Good sharp pictures, but in low light the quality fells.

Reviews.Title: Nice camera, but box was missing USB cable
Reviews.Author: Cameron
Reviews.Content: The camera itself seems to work really well.  The optical zoom is crystal clear every time, even with my slightly shaky hands.  I like the fact that it has so many manual options.  I inevitably sent this camera back because the box was missing the USB cable (I don't have a card reader on my laptop).  I ended up reordering it elsewhere for a little less.  Overall, the camera is nice and I'm excited to take it on upcoming vacations.

Reviews.Title: its ok for a beginner
Reviews.Author: carmen lazar
Reviews.Content: i rec'd the camera in plenty of time, so i was satisfied with the delivery. but the camera is too slow, specially when you try to use the flash, there is a few seconds of hesitation, it will tell you it is trying to use the flash. so, if you are buying this for a kid, then it is ok to do so,, its not complicated to use.  i am surprise that Canon products arent as good as they used to. i guess you cant rely on the name anymore.

Reviews.Title: Not for me.
Reviews.Author: Cpt Zombie Steve
Reviews.Content: This was a gift for someone else but they inform me it's the best camera they have ever used.  So I guess it's a good camera.

Reviews.Title: not what i had hoped for
Reviews.Author: Bernard Lehrman
Reviews.Content: I would prefer a view finder......I had a hard time focusing.......way too long to charge the flash//////was missing all my great shots of the grandchildren waiting for it to charge........I returned it for a different camera

Reviews.Title: Say Cheese
Reviews.Author: Judy A. Yagerlener "Yagermama"
Reviews.Content: I haven't taken many pictures with this yet.  It is replacing one almost identical to it.  Word of warning.  Seawater and this camera do not mix!

Reviews.Title: Canon power shot sx 160
Reviews.Author: Juan D. Arroyo
Reviews.Content: I recieved it before time and in good condition. The packing was not too good but it came to me in good shape.The camera is very good for the price,of course is a canon.Thankyou.Juan

Reviews.Title: This got good reviews
Reviews.Author: Karen M
Reviews.Content: I really hate this camera. It is so not user friendly. It needs a guide book to figure it out (which I printed and tried to find my way around) it isn't even good as a point and shoot. Disappointed so much that I went back to my old kodak easy share and I find it takes better picture.

Reviews.Title: Had problems taking pictures
Reviews.Author: Kevin
Reviews.Content: When I started to take pictures they will have black spots on left and right side corners. I returned the camera.

Reviews.Title: Not Worth It
Reviews.Author: girlforgod
Reviews.Content: I searched a very long time for the perfect camera. I found this  camera it was everything I wanted or at least so I thought. Instead of using a rechargeable battery like most cameras this camera uses AA batteries which only lasts for 20-40 pictures. I am returning this camera just because of the batteries it is not worth the camera. Although other than the batteries this camera is amazing! perfect zoom and settings.

Reviews.Title: Poor design, except for its ability to use readily-available AA batteries.
Reviews.Author: Liz E
Reviews.Content: This camera is nice in that it uses AA batteries, so it'll be easy to change/replace the batteries no matter where I am.  On the other hand, it has a slower shutter reaction time than I'm used to.  I haven't timed it, but it feels slower than my Canon SX100 IS.  (I bought the SX160 because the SX100 videos had poor resolution.)  One thing that's definitely unsatisfactory about the SX160 is how long you have to wait for the flash to charge before you can use it.  That says something in itself.  A built-in flash that has to charge?  That's a throwback to the 80s!  Makes me think of the old Vivitar camera I grew up with.  On top of it all, the camera body feels like cheap plastic.  Sadly, except for the video ability, my SX100 has the SX160 totally beat, hands down.  I won't be buying cameras in this series anymore.

Reviews.Title: Sucks the life out of batteries!
Reviews.Author: DHill
Reviews.Content: I thought this camera was pretty good for the price.  However I seem to be making up the price difference in buying batteries.  I took this on vacation and I had to put new batteries in 1-3 times a day!!!!  Seems a bit much. As soon as I start recording a video the low battery icon starts flashing. Not very reassuring.  And yes it does take quite a while to get the flash going. I've had to ask people to wait...wait...wait for it....almost ready and the moment is long gone when the flash finally goes off.The picture quality and zoom capability is good. There are picture filters on the camera but not explained in the instruction booklet.I think Canon has been around long enough that I expected better from them.

Reviews.Title: Focus and color not sharp.
Reviews.Author: William Kuehn
Reviews.Content: We returned this camera because the photos were not sharp and the colors did not look right.  We replaced it with a Nikon L820 which cost a little more but produced a much sharper, better quality picture.

Reviews.Title: Great quality
Reviews.Author: Helen Sherrod
Reviews.Content: I have like Canon cameras since 1978, when I purchased my Canon AE1 SLR camera.  Film or digital cameras, always.

Reviews.Title: Great product
Reviews.Author: luis fernando hernandez vargas
Reviews.Content: Everything ok.thank you for your product is a excellent price and qualityregardsmerry chrismas and happy new year

Reviews.Title: Great Camera
Reviews.Author: Amazon Customer
Reviews.Content: took some great picture. Great Camera for the money! was able to take some great shots in New Orleans with this Camera.

Reviews.Title: Very disappointed with DavisMax fulfillment
Reviews.Author: Ginger E. Gordon
Reviews.Content: This was a very carefully made choice for a very special Christmas present.  When the box was opened there was no interface cable and no CD to upload pics to computer (even though the booklet contained in the box says these are included).  I sent an email to the Seller only to get the response that they have no interface cables. I have been shopping with Amazon for many years and will continue to do so, but I will NEVER purchase another item fulfilled by DavisMAX!! Now, in order to complete this gift I have to try to find an interface cable and CD.....

Reviews.Title: Not what I expected
Reviews.Author: Nick S. Lutz "sysanalyst"
Reviews.Content: Introduction:Camera was purchased to replace a Nikon L22 purchased last year on Amazon.com. The primary use was to take pictures of items to be sold on a large wEst coast Big Auction companY. Upgraded to the SX160, or so I thought... Used this camera for a couple of days and found the pictures to be grainy, blurry, while colors were not true, always washed out with blues being emphasized. While the pictures are of high resolution, they are not as nice as those taken with the Nikon L22. Even after adjusting ISO to low levels and using heavy duty lighting, the pictures were grainy and blurry; my customers did notice with comments like; "buy a new camera", "can you send me some better pics", and "stop using your iPhone for your pics". Amazon as always, is first rate to their buyers; they took back the camera for a full refund.Pros:Lightweight, pretty color, nicely packagedCons:Takes nasty, grainy, blurry pictures despite camera mode/setting changes and adjustments.Summary:Perhaps I received a "lemon", but "it is what it is".  If you don't really care what your pictures look like, this camera would be a great camera for you. Beyond that, I don't find anything useful about the SX160.Note: I gave the L22 to my nephew as a gift so without a camera to work with, I purchased a Canon T3 DSLR at a large electronics FiRm in YeS, California for $350. Will give that a try.********************* UPDATE ******************************The Canon T3 DSLR arrived two days ago and I'm happy to report that it is absolutely AWESOME. The picture quality is stunning, the photos are crisp and sharp, and the colors are perfect even when set to auto mode. I'd recommend the T3 to anyone needing a good online auction camera. Glad this finally worked out. Unbelievable price on the T3 as well (under $350 with free shipping).

Reviews.Title: all was ok thanks, I was I requested, all was ok, thanks a lot for all, I will buying more
Reviews.Author: Norman
Reviews.Content: all was ok thanks, I was I requested, all was ok, thanks a lot for all, I will buying more

Reviews.Title: Adequate for most, but lacking speed and ISO range.
Reviews.Author: Mike Skrzynski
Reviews.Content: I've been spoiled by my DSLR. This camera cannot compete with it, though I didn't expect that it would. It's just that I did expect a little more of it. I was frustrated by the lag between shots, and that the low-light shots were terrible. It was even a bit softer than my iPod in daylight. The biggest thing it does have going for it is the zoom, which could get me to places that were otherwise inaccessible.I like that it's light and compact, as well as manual settings to play with. Though, as I said, I've had my DSLR too long to go back to a point-and-shoot. This gets the job done, but that's about it.

Reviews.Title: Not happy at all...sending it back
Reviews.Author: Kristie911
Reviews.Content: After a lot of shopping, reading reviews and asking friends, I decided to ignore the bad reviews here on Amazon and order this camera.  Out of the box, it seemed okay.  It was bigger than I wanted but thought I could live with it.  I put the SD card in and snapped a few pics.  They were terrible.  I took pictures of my daughter in a well lit room.  They were very dark and blurry.  I flipped up the flash and it took about 30 seconds for it to work.  The pic was light and blurry.  I tried pics outside and they were blurry too.  I never got a good crisp picture in the dozen or so I took.  And yes, I am familiar with how a point and shoot works, I was holding the button halfway down so it would focus before snapping the picture but they were always out of focus or dark or both.  I found a Nikon at another store for a cheaper price and it takes considerably clearer pictures.  This Canon is going back and I will not buy another Canon product again...I have never been more disappointed in a camera.

Reviews.Title: Gud point and shoot although a lil bulky
Reviews.Author: akiamu
Reviews.Content: I was looking for a camera to replace my Olympus point-and-shoot whose LCD developed a black spot. I was initially inclining towards the Canon SX-500 IS because of the 30x zoom but soon realized I never really used the zoom on my original camera. I decided to go for this one primarily because of the price as I do not consider myself skilled at anything other than taking the occasional pictures when I visit places.Pros:1) 16 MP so clear pictures.2) 16x zoom ( although I dont use it much it is a gud add on to have ).3) The separate video recording button is cool although seems to be on most cams nowadays.4) The various preset modes are also pretty nice to use. I tried my hands at a few although there are a lot more.Cons:1) No li-ion batteries. The original batteries which came with the cam ran out after arnd 50 shots. You can easily purchase rechargable ones but still requires that you carry another charger.2) The night mode is not the most clear.3) At high ISO you see a lot of noise in the picture.4) A lil bulky.All in all a decent point and shoot. The best point in its favor is the price tag.

Reviews.Title: Defective but CS is good
Reviews.Author: G. Stone
Reviews.Content: Had to send it in to Canon after 2 months.....they replaced it.  Hope round 2 is better and I have a camera for a change

Reviews.Title: The lens barrel stopped functioning after  about 2 dozen shooting  occasions .I have owned 8
Reviews.Author: Al Clerihue
Reviews.Content: canon cameras and have never had a problem. I also have been using an sx30is and I am very satisfied with it.

Reviews.Title: Beware
Reviews.Author: Peter Chase
Reviews.Content: For some reason this camera has a higher star rating then it deserves. It burns through batteries, takes poor pictures and if you want to catch a quick and unexpected shot, forget it. I was very disappointed by this Canon product.

Reviews.Title: Canon Camera SX160
Reviews.Author: LORETTA CHAVEZ
Reviews.Content: I did not like this camera. I didn't like the small picture that came up on the screen with all the diagrams and charts and stuff showing instead of a full screen of my pix. Too complicated to use for me. I will keep a look out for a simpler camera.

Reviews.Title: Haven't used it yet - no memory card - AT ALL
Reviews.Author: L&N;'s Mommie
Reviews.Content: No memory card was included so Christmas morning wasn't so fun for my daughter.  I just signed on to purchase one so she'll actually open the box again.... :-(

Reviews.Title: A little less than expected
Reviews.Author: Crackers
Reviews.Content: The camera was much bigger than I thought it would be and the camera requires two AA batteries for power.  I would have preferred a rechargeable one cell battery for the camera

Reviews.Title: Too big, bulky and heavy for ease of use, slow flash recharge
Reviews.Author: Jennifer Milligan
Reviews.Content: I originally wanted this camera because it offered amazing optical zoom at a great price. The AA battery was an added bonus. However, I ultimately returned the camera because of the following:Too bulky. This camera is not really a pocket camera. Bigger than your typical point and shoot (due to the size of the lens I'm sure) it doesn't comfortable fit into a purse or coat pocket. In addition, if you have small hands it is difficult to operate one handed.Too heavy. This camera is quite heavy, again I'm sure it's due to the large lens. If you do put it in your purse it seems to drag it down. In addition, because of the weight it is difficult for someone with small hands to operate one handed. I have slightly compromised strength in my right hand due to injury, and it was uncomfortable to try to operate with one hand; which I need to do because I use it for my job and the other hand is full of my clipboard.Flash. You have to push a button to manually pop the flash up. If you are trying to operate the camera one handed it is pretty difficult to get the flash up. Then of course, you have to push it back down before you put it away. The flash also takes a really long time to charge, which is pretty annoying.Body. The body is plastic, and feels cheap. I'm sure this is to cut down on weight because the  camera already weighs a ton, but it just doesn't really feel quality.I didn't use this camera enough to comment on the quality of the photos, the above issues were enough that I did even want to use the camera more than once,

Reviews.Title: defective camera - I will try another
Reviews.Author: Stan Boes "reader"
Reviews.Content: The camera was not functioning correctly when I received it.  The zoom function did not work, the shutter button was functional intermittently.  I returned the camera and was fully refunded.

Reviews.Title: Wouldn't recommend
Reviews.Author: angelbit787 "me"
Reviews.Content: Pictures are constantly blurry. Worst camera I ever had. I even paid more than I wanted to on this camera thinking it would be better, I should of stuck with a cheaper camera would of got better pictures. Very disappointed

Reviews.Title: You'd think 16 Megapixels would make it a nicer camera than one with 12
Reviews.Author: Barbara A Brenner
Reviews.Content: I ordered this as an upgrade to my older Canon PowerShot but it has less options and is bulkier. Also it takes bad action shots which is something I need in a camera. Also Amazon sent me the black one, not a major deal but now I can't return it.

Reviews.Title: Herb
Reviews.Author: Herbert Rixse
Reviews.Content: I bought it as a gift, but then I found out the person had just got a new camera, so the camera I bought is still in it's shipping box unopened.  It being a camera I have no use for so I can't give it a rating.

Reviews.Title: Camera
Reviews.Author: Virginia
Reviews.Content: SIze it is bigger than I want. There is a pause before the flash  . I like the feature to put the pictures on my computer,!!!

Reviews.Title: Too heavy
Reviews.Author: Dora Podborits
Reviews.Content: This camera is quite heavy comparing  with other similar types I had before, Kodak by example.I don' like it

Reviews.Title: Ok Camera
Reviews.Author: keesha
Reviews.Content: This is an ok camera but it is not what I was expecting.  I guess they are correct when they say, "you get what you pay for".

Reviews.Title: Poor quality pictures
Reviews.Author: Suzanne
Reviews.Content: I have a dslr camera and wanted something small for a trip.  The pictures were of poor quality, especially compared to my cousin's pictures that she took with a point and shoot camera of a different brand. The only time it took clear pictures was in daylight.  It took awhile for pictures to snap as well and I missed shots.  Very, very disappointed.

Reviews.Title: Neat aa battery product
Reviews.Author: billp37
Reviews.Content: Upgrade to Fuji a600  with 1 gig of ds memory wanted.  a600 works excelllent. But USB conntects only last limited number of times.a600 purchased in 2006 from best buy for about $200. AA battery powred is requirement.  No specialized battery charging camera rejected.  SX 160  16is meets expections with 16 gig transcend class 10 sdhc. [Amazon $164] . Canon software loaded properly on three  xp laptops but did not on desktop. Why?  Investigation in progress.  From retired iso 9002 certified windows device driver writer. Google' scorpion silhouette named james'

Reviews.Title: BUMMER
Reviews.Author: Frances G.
Reviews.Content: Just received my camera that I ordered to take on an upcoming trip.  Was pretty excited until I opened the box and camera and found NO memory card,,,,,,,,,,,,,, I have purchased at least 4 cameras in the last 10 years and every one of them came with a memory card.You always had the option to upgrade to a larger memory card BUT it always came with one.Now I have to go out and purchase one in the middle of all the packing and prep work for the trip ,,,,,,, thanks for taking ALL the fun out of getting my new camera.Hope the pictures won't be as disappointing as receiving this.  You may want to stipulate on your ad that camera comes WITHOUT memory card.

Reviews.Title: looks cool
Reviews.Author: Azra :)
Reviews.Content: this camera looks amazing, function perfect... i have nikon coolpix s8200 also... compair to this canon my nikon is good.. bcoz this canon dont have perfect clearity.. but only its look so nice... :(
